full_text: 📻 I was on Morning Ireland on RTÉ Radio 1 this morning to discuss the whitewash that is the Navan Hospital 'review'. Have a listen back here. 👇  https://t.co/erbzmrXfaJ

The Terms of Reference of the Navan Hospital review (just now published) confirming that the possibility of investing in and keeping the A&E open WILL NOT BE CONSIDERED. Outrageous. #SaveNavanHospital https://t.co/ygNmiGdCKe

This ‘review’ has all the makings of a whitewash. Window-dressing to deliver on the HSE’s intention to close Navan A&E. (They aren’t even considering an option that keeps the A&E open!). And all under the watchful eye of Fianna Fáil & Fine Gael. Disgrace.  https://t.co/ALbDxqWQXN

I will be on @LMFMRADIO at 9.15am this morning discussing the refusal by Min. Stephen Donnelly and the HSE to give details of the ongoing review into the future of Navan Hospital. Tune in if you can. 📻 https://t.co/hioN5bvYAW
A great day at Moynalty Steam Threshing. The best and most historic of equipment on display. Great to have a bumper crowd. Well done to all involved. https://t.co/iIg7FH5C6d
Yeah, 100 years of Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael… https://t.co/IuA0FRV4Ac

I'm reminded of this👇🏼. We're fortunate to have an incredible wind resource. It can be used to benefit the many or the few. There is a necessary role for the private sector, but FF/FG/Greens are all too comfortable leaving Ireland as a developer's playground. https://t.co/5gYjMXeaa6 https://t.co/s9ONIjhyke

The government must introduce a WINDFALL TAX on big-profiting energy companies and redirect the money back into people’s pockets.  The United Nations have called on governments to introduce such a measure which other governments across Europe have done. @PearseDoherty https://t.co/I9N1fBI7dK
(6/6) https://t.co/p87Utk7woo
It’s been 5 years since Sinn Féin published our Microgeneration Support Scheme Bill 2017, so there is no excuse for this ongoing delay. (5/6)   https://t.co/h5W5iIOIfY

The state is missing an opportunity for positive contagion.   If others can see they can reduce their electricity bills this way, it will help increase solar PV installations.   There is also huge opportunity in other areas, like solar for schools. (4/6)   https://t.co/KrT2pSWvuA

Solar PV can help households cut skyrocketing electricity bills while also reducing our emissions.   Scientists at UCC have found that a quarter of all electricity needed by households could be produced by putting solar panels on domestic rooftops. (3/6)  https://t.co/ijfxTlWQjZ

This is despite Minister Ryan repeatedly assuring us this scheme would be in place by July.   Those households who installed solar PV deserve to get paid now for the renewable energy they are sending to the grid. (2/6)   https://t.co/EkHVCLRFgU

This week I contacted the 12 main electricity suppliers here to ask if they are paying microgenerators for the renewable energy they are sending to the grid.   Only 2 confirmed they were.   Most said they have not even decided what unit rate they will pay yet. (1/6) https://t.co/uZrtXVduzZ

Details of @HSELive 'National Working Group' review into the future of Navan Hospital must be published. It will have zero credibility otherwise. Meath Ministers McEntee, Byrne & English need to stop acting like commentators.  https://t.co/jnm1DRSGVp https://t.co/88QlkC4hxh
I was happy to join the @SavetheBoyne  protest at Slane Bridge on Saturday (along with Art & Éadaoin). The campaign continues.   https://t.co/0DuZ7E6avW

Great crowd at Slane Bridge today for the ⁦@SavetheBoyne⁩ Picnic Protest against Dawn Meats’ application to pump wastewater into the River Boyne. Walkers and kayakers are heading on to Drogheda now. Well done to all involved.   The campaign continues. https://t.co/eP63mzkoSJ

@Irishwildlife @sinnfeinireland SF are not party to sectoral emissions negotiations - by law. We have been denied access to essential information that would inform any position. In the absence of that info we have stated clearly - 51% by 2030 must be met in ceilings, & every sector must do its fair share. https://t.co/dftCS0up59

Posters up and out in support of the Meath ladies before next Sunday’s All-Ireland Final against Kerry. Get along to Croke Park to cheer them on if you can. 🟢🟡 #AnMhíAbú ⁦⁦@meathladiesMLGF⁩ https://t.co/kiIaxUba4Y
Common sense has prevailed. AIB have decided to abandon their ill-conceived plan to remove cash services from 70 branches. Thank you to everyone who signed our petition.   https://t.co/JXeb9gUOFE

Target: -4.8% Result: +4.7% is what happens when you resist at every turn (as this Govt has) putting Just Transition Principles at the heart of #climateaction.  Every scheme an inequitable scheme. Every target a missed target.   https://t.co/asDyI1TDdd

Downgrading of Kells AIB branch is a regressive move that must be reversed. It is time for the government to act & tell AIB that after a €20.7 billion State bailout it can’t walk away & abandon communities without banking services.   ✍️ SIGN THE PETITION: https://t.co/AdQSR87xoK https://t.co/oFkolosvtW

@DanielTMurray Your position is clear. I hope mine is too: 1) SF are not party to sectoral emissions negotiations - by law. 2) We have been denied access to essential information that would inform any position. 3) 51% by 2030 must be met in ceilings, & every sector must do its fair share.

.@DanielTMurray, the CCAC's advice is just one element that will inform the sectoral emissions ceilings negotiations. We want, and have sought, the rest. We have been denied it.👇🏼To suggest otherwise is disingenuous. We won't pluck a figure out of the air. https://t.co/vpGbUDMJxg https://t.co/yJl2dG8mWa
🏠 New 3 bed semis starting at €485,000 in #Ashbourne. System is beyond broken. What chance has anyone?!

@Irishwildlife @sinnfeinireland Sinn Féin supports the carbon budgets. We agree the 51% reduction by 2030 and that every sector must do their fair share. The sectoral emissions ceilings are a matter for Govt. Sinn Féin are specifically excluded from the process. We will not pick a number out of thin air.

@whittledaway @sinnfeinireland @MaryLouMcDonald Sinn Féin supports the carbon budgets. We agree the 51% reduction by 2030 and that every sector must do their fair share. The sectoral emissions ceilings are a matter for Govt. Sinn Féin are specifically excluded from the process. We will not pick a number out of thin air.

Govt will today redirect €40m funding FROM retrofitting to pay for data centre-induced emergency (gas/diesel powered) electricity….that companies will charge a premium for. Ring-fenced carbon tax my eye. Ordinary workers & families paying on the double for govt incompetence.
